p: Controlled climate room experiments have demonstrated that photoperiod alone is sufficient to induce dormant buds at growth-promoting temperatures, and that subsequent chilling is required to release dormancy and enhance freezing tolerance [ 2, 13, 16, 17]. The role of temperature in dormancy establishment has remained controversial. Classic literature suggests that some trees, such as Populus, Malus and Acer, lose the capacity to form dormant TBs under low temperature conditions [ 18– 21]. This would make successful north ward migration unlikely. Contrary to this, other studies propose that low temperature on its own could induce the establishment of dormant buds or contribute to it [ 22– 27].
